chunks.description: Unique identifier for the inventory item, used in ERP systems for tracking stock levels, transactions, and reporting in modules like inventory management, procurement, and sales order processing.
The primary name of the item in the local language, essential for user-friendly identification in ERP interfaces during purchase requisitions, sales quotes, and warehouse operations.
The item's name in a foreign language, supporting multilingual ERP environments for international trade, export documentation, and global supply chain management.
Detailed textual description of the item, utilized in ERP for catalog management, quality control checks, and generating product specifications in manufacturing or sales modules.
Foreign language version of the item description, aiding in cross-border ERP use cases such as international vendor negotiations, compliance reporting, and multilingual customer catalogs.
The base unit of measure for the item (e.g., each, kg), critical in ERP for accurate quantity calculations in inventory transactions, billing, and material requirement planning (MRP).
The largest allowable unit of measure for the item, used in ERP to enforce packaging constraints during bulk ordering, shipping, and warehouse space optimization.
The maximum size of the parent item or container, relevant in ERP for hierarchical item structures like kits or assemblies in production planning and inventory valuation.
Code representing the item's group classification, enabling ERP grouping for analytics, such as cost analysis by class in financial reporting or procurement strategies.
Name of the item's group classification, providing readable labels in ERP dashboards for inventory categorization, trend analysis, and group-based access controls.
Numeric identifier for the item's associated activity, used in ERP to link items to specific processes like manufacturing runs or service activities for cost allocation and performance tracking.
Name of the item's associated activity, facilitating ERP reporting on activity-based costing, workflow automation, and integration with project management modules.
Code for the main group the item belongs to, supporting ERP hierarchical classification for high-level inventory segmentation in budgeting and strategic sourcing.
Name of the main group, used in ERP for intuitive navigation in item master data maintenance and group-level sales forecasting.
Code for the subgroup within the main group, allowing finer ERP categorization for targeted promotions, stock rotation policies, and subcategory analysis.
Name of the subgroup, enhancing ERP usability in reports like subgroup profitability analysis or vendor performance by subcategory.
Code for a further subdivided group, enabling deep ERP hierarchical structures for detailed inventory control in large-scale operations like retail chains.
Name of the under-subgroup, useful in ERP for precise filtering in queries, such as under-subgroup stock aging reports or compliance audits.
Code for an assistant or auxiliary group (likely a typo for "ASSISTANT"), used in ERP to assign secondary classifications for cross-functional analysis, like marketing or R&D groupings.
Name of the assistant group, supporting ERP in alternative views of inventory data for specialized use cases like product bundling or seasonal campaigns.
Code for a detailed group level, providing granular ERP classification for micro-level management, such as variant tracking in manufacturing.
Name of the detail group, aiding in ERP detailed reporting, like cost breakdowns or quality metrics by detail group.
Code for an alternative group (likely a typo for "ALTERNATIVE"), allowing ERP flexibility in reclassifying items for scenario planning or market adaptations.
Name of the alternative group, used in ERP for comparative analysis, such as alternative grouping impacts on inventory turnover ratios.
Numeric identifier for the item's category, essential for ERP categorization in procurement catalogs, tax calculations, and category-based pricing strategies.
Name of the item category, facilitating user-friendly ERP searches and reports, like category-wise demand forecasting.
Flag indicating if the item is a kit (assembly of components), critical in ERP for bill of materials (BOM) management, kitting processes, and sales order fulfillment.
Flag for whether the item uses expiration dates, vital in ERP for perishables management, shelf-life tracking, and compliance in industries like food or pharmaceuticals.
Flag for batch number tracking, used in ERP for quality control, recall management, and traceability in manufacturing and distribution.
Flag for serial number tracking, enabling ERP serialization for warranty management, asset tracking, and regulatory compliance in electronics or machinery.
Flag for attaching documents or files to the item, supporting ERP document management for specs, certifications, or images in procurement and sales.
Size of the item's packaging, used in ERP for logistics planning, shipping cost calculations, and warehouse slotting optimization.
Overall size of the item, relevant in ERP for space allocation in warehouses, transportation planning, and product design integrations.
Calculated area of the item, aiding ERP in floor space management, layout planning, and cost per square unit analysis.
Weight of the item, crucial for ERP freight calculations, inventory handling safety, and weight-based pricing in supply chain modules.
Global Trade Item Number (GTIN) code, used in ERP for barcode integration, e-commerce synchronization, and international trade standardization.
Harmonized System (HS) code for customs classification, essential in ERP for import/export compliance, tariff calculations, and global trade reporting.
Code for the manufacturer, linking items to suppliers in ERP for vendor performance tracking, sourcing decisions, and quality audits.
Alternative code for the item (likely a typo for "ALTERNATIVE"), providing ERP flexibility for cross-referencing with legacy systems or vendor codes.
Flag or code for MRP inclusion, used in ERP to drive demand planning, reorder points, and production scheduling.
Type of document associated with the movement (e.g., invoice, receipt), central to ERP transaction processing and audit trails.
Name of the document type, enhancing ERP readability in transaction histories and compliance reports.
Method of payment for the transaction, integrated in ERP with accounts payable/receivable for cash flow management and financial reconciliation.
Name of the payment method, used in ERP for filtering reports like payment aging or method-based discount analysis.
Subtype of the document (e.g., credit note), allowing ERP nuanced transaction classification for accurate accounting entries.
Name of the document subtype, supporting detailed ERP analytics, such as subtype-specific revenue recognition.
Code for the warehouse where the movement occurs, key in ERP for multi-location inventory control and transfer orders.
Name of the warehouse, providing user-friendly labels in ERP stock queries and location-based reporting.
Code for the warehouse group, enabling ERP aggregation for regional stock analysis or group-level replenishment.
Name of the warehouse group, used in ERP dashboards for high-level visibility into grouped inventory metrics.
Date of the document/transaction, critical for ERP time-based reporting, period closing, and historical trend analysis.
Numeric identifier for the financial period, linking movements to ERP fiscal calendars for accurate period-end adjustments.
Name of the financial period, facilitating ERP period-specific financial statements and variance analysis.
Indicator for incoming or outgoing movement, fundamental in ERP for stock balance calculations and flow tracking.
Name describing the incoming/outgoing type, enhancing ERP report interpretability for inventory audits.
Total quantity of the item in the transaction, used in ERP for updating stock levels and quantity-based alerts.
Net quantity sold after adjustments, key in ERP sales analytics for revenue forecasting and performance metrics.
Quantity received into inventory, supporting ERP receipt processing and vendor delivery evaluations.
Quantity issued from inventory, integral to ERP for shipment tracking and demand fulfillment.
Quantity received for free (e.g., samples), used in ERP to track promotional items without affecting cost averages.
Quantity issued for free, aiding ERP in managing giveaways or samples in marketing budgets.
Net incoming after deductions, providing ERP accurate net stock inflows for planning.
Net outgoing after adjustments, essential for ERP net consumption tracking in production.
Current available stock quantity, used in ERP for real-time availability checks in order processing.
Cost of the stock involved, critical for ERP inventory valuation methods like FIFO or average costing.
VAT amount on the transaction, integrated in ERP with tax compliance modules for reporting and refunds.
Total discount applied, used in ERP for pricing strategy analysis and customer loyalty programs.
Miscellaneous amounts (e.g., fees), allowing ERP flexibility in capturing non-standard transaction elements.
VAT on other amounts, ensuring ERP accurate tax calculations on additional charges.
Detailed breakdown of discount, supporting ERP granular discount tracking for negotiations.
VAT on detailed discount, used in ERP for precise tax-inclusive discount reporting.
Second level of discount detail, enabling multi-tier discount structures in ERP sales modules.
VAT on second discount detail, maintaining ERP tax integrity in complex pricing.
Third level of discount detail, for advanced ERP discount hierarchies in bulk deals.
VAT on third discount detail, ensuring comprehensive tax handling in ERP.
Average cost of the item in the warehouse, used in ERP for moving average valuation and profitability calculations.
Initial length dimension of the item, relevant in ERP for dimensional inventory in industries like textiles.
Initial width dimension, aiding ERP space and packaging optimizations.
Initial height dimension, used in ERP for volumetric calculations in shipping.
Type of account detail, linking inventory to ERP general ledger for financial integration.
Code for the customer involved, essential for ERP customer-specific transaction tracking and CRM integration.
Name of the customer, providing readable context in ERP sales and delivery reports.
Code for the vendor, key in ERP procurement for supplier management and purchase order linking.
Name of the vendor, used in ERP for vendor performance dashboards.
Code for the cost center, enabling ERP cost allocation to departments or projects.
Name of the cost center, facilitating cost center-based budgeting in ERP.
Numeric identifier for the project, linking items to ERP project management for expense tracking.
Name of the project, used in ERP for project-specific inventory reports.
Number for the activity, supporting activity-based management in ERP.
Name of the activity, enhancing ERP workflow and costing analysis.
Expiration date of the item, critical for ERP expiry alerts and waste minimization.
Batch identifier, used in ERP for traceability and quality recalls.
Numeric code for the company, enabling multi-company ERP setups for consolidated reporting.
Name of the company, providing context in shared ERP environments.
Number for the branch, supporting ERP multi-branch operations and localized stock control.
Name of the branch, used in branch-wise performance metrics.
Year associated with the branch, possibly for fiscal year tracking in ERP.
User associated with the branch (possibly incomplete), for ERP user-level access and audit logs.
Numeric code for the country, essential for ERP international compliance and currency handling.
Name of the country, aiding in geographic reporting.
Numeric code for the province, used in ERP for regional tax and logistics.
Name of the province, for location-based analytics.
Numeric code for the city, supporting detailed address management in ERP.
Name of the city, used in shipping and customer mapping.
Code for the region, enabling broader geographic grouping in ERP.
Name of the region, for regional sales forecasting.
Date of incoming movement, key for ERP receipt timing and vendor evaluation.
Transaction-specific length, allowing overrides for variable dimensions in ERP.
Transaction-specific width, for accurate per-transaction calculations.
Transaction-specific height, used in dynamic shipping quotes.
Flag for seasonal items, aiding ERP in seasonal demand planning and promotions.
Flag for reusable or exchangeable items, supporting ERP circular economy tracking and returns management.
Brand name of the item, essential for ERP brand-specific marketing and inventory segmentation.
Name of the manufacturing company, used in ERP for supplier diversification strategies.
Country of manufacture, critical for ERP compliance with trade regulations and origin labeling.
Document serial number uniquely identifying each financial posting entry within the ERP system.
Type of financial document such as journal voucher, payment, or receipt used in the general ledger.
Unit number or business unit associated with the financial transaction.
General ledger account code related to the financial posting.
Account name in the local language used for reporting purposes.
Account name in the foreign or system language used in ERP reports.
Specifies the account type such as asset, liability, expense, or revenue.
Flag indicating whether this entry is part of the opening balance for the fiscal year.
Flag denoting if the posting is related to currency exchange differences.
Detailed sub-account code for more granular tracking within the chart of accounts.
Name of the detailed sub-account for financial classification.
Specifies the type of detailed account such as customer, vendor, or bank account.
Currency code used for the transaction (e.g., USD, EUR).
Unique document number assigned to the financial transaction.
Date when the document was issued or created.
General ledger posting date used for accounting period control.
Description or name of the document type.
Salesman or representative code linked to the transaction.
Salesman name or description related to the sales entry.
Collector code associated with payment or collection entries.
Collector name associated with the financial transaction.
Reference number for cross-linking related financial documents.
Manual number entered by user for document tracking.
Description or remarks about the financial transaction.
Debit amount in local currency.
Debit amount in foreign currency.
Credit amount in local currency.
Credit amount in foreign currency.
Branch number where the employee is assigned.
Unique employee number used across the ERP system.
Employee last name as recorded in HR records.
Employee first name as recorded in HR records.
Employee status such as active, suspended, or terminated.
Job title or position name assigned to the employee.
Manager name or ID supervising the employee.
Job grade number defining employee level in the organization.
Job grade description or name.
Type of employment such as full-time, part-time, or contract.
Current employment status reflecting employee's availability or position.
Nationality code for the employee.
Nationality name or description.
Gender of the employee.
Marital status of the employee.
Religion of the employee as recorded in HR master data.
Level or grade within the organizational hierarchy.
Citizenship or national ID type description.
Employee start work date.
Group or department number employee belongs to.
Name of the group or department.
Currency used for employee payroll and compensation.
Employee national identification number.
Employee date of birth.
Date the employee ended work or contract termination date.
Payment method such as bank transfer, cash, or cheque.
End date of employee's probation or test period.
Type number representing the kind of purchase document.
Unique purchase document number used for supplier invoice tracking.
Document serial number within the purchasing module.
Date of purchase invoice issuance.
Manual entry date entered by user for record adjustment.
Currency used in the purchase transaction.
Exchange rate applied for currency conversion at the time of purchase.
Stock rate or valuation rate used for inventory accounting.
Warehouse code where purchased goods are received or stored.
Vendor code identifying the supplier in the ERP vendor master.
Vendor or supplier name.
Cash payment amount for the purchase invoice.
Bank payment amount related to supplier transactions.
Credit payment amount related to supplier transactions.
Tax amount applied on the purchase invoice.
Total purchase bill amount in foreign currency.
Total purchase bill amount in local currency.
Due date for payment of the purchase invoice.
Purchase document description or remarks.
Username of the user who created the purchase bill record.
Creation date of the purchase bill record in the system.
Purchase document number that uniquely identifies each purchase bill header record; used to link item details with the main purchase bill.
Document serial number used to distinguish multiple documents or transactions under the same document type and year.
Sequential line number of the item within the purchase bill; represents item order in the document.
Financial or fiscal year associated with the purchase transaction, used for reporting and accounting purposes.
Unit number representing the business unit, department, or branch responsible for this purchase transaction.
Unique code identifying the purchased item or product in the inventory master list.
Unit of measure (e.g., piece, box, kg) used for the purchased item in this transaction.
Item size or packaging specification that defines the variant or configuration of the purchased item.
Warehouse code where the purchased items are received or stored.
Expiry date of the item, applicable for perishable or time-sensitive goods.
Item segment or category reference used for grouping similar products for reporting or cost analysis.
Quantity of the item purchased in this transaction line.
Quantity of items received free of charge as part of the purchase deal or promotion.
Additional free quantity of items added beyond the standard free quantity in the deal.
Total free quantity combining standard and additional free items for the purchase line.
Main quantity of the purchased item excluding any free quantity or bonus items.
Free quantity corresponding to the main item in the purchase line.
Total main free quantity combining all free units associated with the main item.
Unit price of the purchased item before taxes and discounts.
Stock cost or valuation cost of the item for inventory accounting.
Tax percentage applied to the item in this purchase line.
Calculated tax amount applied to the item based on the tax percentage.
Other charge amount applied to this item, such as freight, handling, or service charges.
Discount amount applied to the item based on purchase agreements or promotions.
Additional discount amount provided beyond the standard discount for this item.
Total item price before applying any discounts, taxes, or charges (quantity  unit price).
Total discount amount applied to this item including all types of discounts.
Total other charges accumulated for the item including freight and handling costs.
Total tax amount applied to the item after calculation across all applicable tax rates.
Total of all additional discounts applied to this item.
Final total amount of the item after applying discounts, taxes, and other charges.
Total stock cost value of the purchased item line for inventory valuation.
Total item price converted into local currency for reporting and accounting.
Total discount amount in local currency for this purchase line.
Total of other charges in local currency for the item line.
Total tax amount in local currency for the purchased item.
Additional discount amount in local currency for the item line.
Final total item amount in local currency including all taxes and charges.
Sub-ledger code level 1 used for financial reporting and detailed account tracking.
Sub-ledger code level 2 for further breakdown of account or cost center allocation.
Sub-ledger code level 3 used for department or sub-account analysis in ERP reports.
Sub-ledger code level 4 defining detailed classification for financial and managerial analysis.
Sub-ledger code level 5 used to map item-level transactions to sub-categories or divisions.
Sub-ledger code level 6 providing the most granular level of financial account detail in ERP.
Type number identifying the sales bill transaction category such as cash, credit, or return.
Document number uniquely identifying each sales bill or invoice.
Document serial number representing the order of sales bills within the same type or branch.
Official date of the sales bill creation, representing the transaction date.
Manual entry date if the sales bill date is entered manually instead of system-generated.
Currency code used for the transaction, e.g., USD, EGP, SAR.
Exchange rate applied between the local and foreign currency for the transaction.
Stock valuation rate used for cost or accounting calculations in the sales bill.
Warehouse code from which the goods were sold or delivered.
Unit number or branch identifier related to the sales transaction.
Flag or indicator showing if the payment was made in cash.
Flag or indicator showing if the payment was made via bank transfer.
Flag indicating if the payment method is on credit terms.
Flag or value showing coupon-based payment usage in the sale.
Flag for payment made directly from an account balance or customer ledger.
Indicator for payment made using customer loyalty points replacement.
Indicator for replacement-based payment or credit adjustment.
Customer code referencing the client involved in the sales bill.
Customer name linked to the sales transaction for billing and reporting.
Customer mobile number used for contact or verification in sales operations.
Account code detail for the customer sub-account used in accounting entries.
Cash account code used for recording cash transactions.
Bank account code used for recording bank-related sales payments.
Detailed sub-account code linked to the bank ledger for payment tracking.
General ledger account code representing the main account for the sales transaction.
Detailed account code specifying the financial sub-category of the transaction.
Type of account detail used for categorizing financial postings.
Sub-level account code linked to a more granular accounting entry.
Total cash payment amount received for the sales bill.
Total amount received through bank transfer or cheque payments.
Total amount recorded as credit sales in this bill.
Total coupon amount applied to the sales bill.
Total amount recorded under account payments.
Amount adjusted due to replacement transactions in the sales bill.
Amount paid using loyalty points replacement system.
Total document value before discounts and taxes.
Total discount amount applied to the sales bill.
Other miscellaneous charges or adjustments applied to the bill.
Total tax amount calculated for the sales transaction.
Additional discount amount provided after initial calculation.
Final total bill amount including taxes and charges in foreign currency.
Final total bill amount converted into local currency.
Salesman code representing the employee responsible for the sale.
Marketer or promoter code associated with the sales transaction.
Collector code for the employee handling payment collection.
Employee code related to the sales or approval process.
Due date for payment completion or delivery related to the sales bill.
Description or remarks field for the sales bill transaction.
Reference number linking this sales bill to another document such as order or quotation.
Manual document number if the sales bill was manually issued.
Commission percentage applicable to the salesperson or marketer.
Tax category number defining applicable tax rules or rates.
Verification flag indicating whether the sales bill was reviewed and approved.
Posting flag showing whether the transaction is posted to the general ledger.
Fiscal year number associated with the sales bill.
Username or user ID of the person who created the sales bill.
Date and time when the sales bill record was created in the system.
Unique document number identifying each sales transaction in the ERP system. Links to the main sales bill record.
Document serial number used to differentiate multiple records under the same sales bill document.
Code of the sold item, referencing the product master to identify the specific item sold in a transaction.
Unit of measure for the sold item, such as piece, box, or kilogram, used for inventory and pricing purposes.
Size or variant of the item being sold, relevant for stock tracking and detailed product differentiation.
Warehouse code from which the item is sold or dispatched, used for inventory and stock movement control.
Expiration date of the sold item, especially relevant for perishable or time-sensitive goods.
Item segment or contract reference, indicating the sales agreement or item group linked to this detail line.
Quantity of the item sold in the transaction, excluding any free quantities or promotions.
Quantity of free items provided in the sale as part of a promotional offer or discount scheme.
Additional free quantity beyond the standard offer, often granted for customer loyalty or special deals.
Total quantity of the item sold including free quantities, representing the overall quantity movement.
Total free quantity of items combined from all promotional or additional offers for the sale.
Main item quantity before conversion or measurement adjustments for multi-unit tracking.
Main quantity of free items provided based on the primary measurement unit.
Additional main free quantity granted on top of the base promotional offer.
Total main quantity, combining regular and free quantities for the transaction line.
Cumulative total of main and free quantities measured in the main unit, used for stock reconciliation.
Unit price of the item before discounts, taxes, or other adjustments are applied.
Stock cost of the item, representing its valuation in inventory or cost of goods sold (COGS).
Applicable tax percentage for the item in the sale, as per the ERP tax configuration.
Tax amount calculated for the item based on its taxable value and applicable tax rate.
Additional charges applied to the item such as freight, packaging, or handling fees.
Discount amount applied to the item based on sales promotions or negotiated terms.
Additional discount amount granted beyond the standard discount, often manually approved.
Total price of the item line before discounts or taxes, calculated as quantity multiplied by unit price.
Total discount amount applied to the item, including base and additional discounts.
Total amount of other charges applied to the item line, such as service fees or packaging costs.
Total tax amount calculated on the item after applying discounts and additional charges.
Sum of additional discounts applied across multiple item levels or promotional schemes.
Final net amount of the item after applying discounts, taxes, and other charges.
Total stock cost for the sold quantity of the item, used for cost analysis and inventory tracking.
Total item price converted to the local currency based on exchange rate settings in the ERP system.
Total discount amount for the item expressed in the local currency.
Total other charges amount in local currency for the item transaction.
Total tax amount for the item in local currency, derived from currency conversion settings.
Additional discount amount in local currency reflecting manual or promotional adjustments.
Final total amount for the item line in local currency after applying all adjustments.
Sub-ledger code level 1 used for financial categorization or reporting in the ERP system.
Sub-ledger code level 2 used for detailed accounting or cost center mapping.
Third-level sub-ledger code for deeper financial analysis and classification.
Fourth-level sub-ledger code supporting granular cost allocation or profit tracking.
Fifth-level sub-ledger code for advanced accounting breakdowns within ERP financials.
Sixth-level sub-ledger code used for complex financial segmentation or detailed reporting structures.
Employee code identifying the salesperson or staff member associated with the sale transaction.
Flag indicating whether the item is a service rather than a physical product, important for taxation and stock handling.
Document detail sequence number for ordering and referencing line items within a sales bill.
Unit number or business unit identifier where the sales transaction was processed.
Fiscal year number associated with the sales document, used for reporting and audit tracking.
Sales return document type number that categorizes the return transaction.
Unique document number identifying the sales return transaction.
Document serial number used for tracking multiple related sales return entries.
The official date when the sales return document was created.
The manual entry date, if the document was manually entered into the system.
Currency code used for the sales return transaction.
Exchange rate applied to convert the transaction currency to base currency.
Stock valuation rate used for returned items.
Warehouse code where the returned items are received or stored.
Organizational unit number responsible for the transaction.
Flag or indicator showing if cash payment was involved in the return process.
Flag indicating if the return payment was processed through a bank transaction.
Indicator if a credit payment method was used for the return.
Flag indicating if coupons were used as part of the return transaction.
Indicates if account balance adjustments were applied as payment method.
Flag indicating if loyalty points were replaced or refunded during the return.
Indicates if the return was handled by replacing the product rather than refunding.
Unique code identifying the customer returning the goods.
Full name of the customer associated with the sales return document.
Customers mobile number for contact or verification purposes.
General ledger account code linked to the return transaction.
Discount amount applied to the total value of returned goods.
Total tax amount calculated on the returned items.
Total value of the sales return bill including discounts and taxes.
Total value of the return bill converted into local currency.
Code of the salesperson responsible for the original sale or handling the return.
Code representing the marketing staff associated with the sales return.
Employee code responsible for processing the sales return document.
Date by which any pending refund or adjustment related to the return is due.
Description of the reason for the sales return, such as defect or overdelivery.
Flag indicating whether the return document has been verified by finance or audit.
Indicator showing whether the sales return has been posted to the general ledger.
Username of the person who created the sales return entry.
Date when the sales return document was entered into the ERP system.
Unique document number identifying the sales return transaction, linked to the return invoice master record.
Document serial number used to differentiate between multiple entries or lines under the same sales return document.
Unique code of the returned item as defined in the item master, representing the product or SKU being returned.
Unit of measurement for the returned item, such as pieces, boxes, or kilograms.
Size or variant specification of the returned item, relevant for inventory and pricing differences.
Warehouse code indicating where the returned item is stored or processed for restocking.
Expiration date of the returned item, mainly used for perishable or limited-shelf-life products.
Item segment or contact information related to the product category or vendor for analysis and reporting.
Quantity of the item being returned by the customer in the sales return transaction.
Quantity of free items returned along with the main item, typically part of promotional offers.
Additional free quantity of items returned due to special discounts or offers.
Total quantity of the item being returned, combining normal and free quantities.
Total free quantity of items included in the sales return document.
Main quantity of items returned excluding promotional or free items.
Main free quantity of items returned related to standard promotional items.
Additional main free quantity returned under extended promotions or manual adjustments.
Total main quantity of items returned combining standard and additional units.
Combined total of main and free quantities of the returned items for the document line.
Unit selling price of the returned item as recorded in the original sales invoice.
Stock cost or cost price of the returned item used for inventory valuation.
Applicable tax percentage for the returned item based on tax rules or product category.
Tax amount associated with the returned item, recalculated from the taxable value.
Other charges amount for the item return such as packaging, freight, or handling costs.
Discount amount applied to the item during the original sale, reversed in the return process.
Additional discount amount applied due to customer loyalty or manual adjustments.
Total selling price of the returned item before applying discounts and taxes.
Total discount amount for the returned item including base and additional discounts.
Total of other charges such as shipping, packaging, or service fees linked to the return line item.
Total tax amount for the returned item line based on tax percentage and taxable value.
Cumulative total of all additional discounts applied to the item return.
Total net amount for the returned item after applying discounts, taxes, and charges.
Total stock cost of returned items for valuation and cost accounting.
Total selling price of the returned item converted into the local currency.
Total discount amount for the returned item in the local currency equivalent.
Total of other charges for the returned item converted into the local currency.
Total tax amount for the returned item in local currency.
Additional discount amount for the returned item converted into local currency.
Total net amount for the returned item in local currency after all adjustments.
Sub-ledger level 1 code for financial posting related to the return item, linking to accounting control accounts.
Sub-ledger level 2 code for detailed financial or departmental classification of the return transaction.
Third-level sub-ledger code for analytical accounting or business unit segmentation.
Fourth-level sub-ledger code used for project or cost center-level tracking of the return.
Fifth-level sub-ledger classification used for deeper accounting granularity of return transactions.
Sixth-level sub-ledger classification for detailed cost allocation or consolidation reporting.
Reference document number of the original sales invoice related to this return transaction.
Serial number of the referenced original sales invoice document for linkage to the return entry.
Employee code of the salesperson or staff responsible for processing the sales return.
Flag indicating whether the returned item is a service (non-inventory item) or a physical product.
Document detail sequence number representing the order of the line item in the return document.
Unit number identifying the business unit, store, or branch processing the sales return.
Financial or fiscal year number associated with the sales return document.
Unique identifier for each manufacturing work order used to track production tasks in the ERP system.
Date when the work order was created, used to plan and schedule production activities.
Indicates the origin or source of the work order, such as sales orders, forecasts, or manual entry.
Code identifying the manufactured item or product linked to the work order.
Category or classification of the item, used for grouping products in production planning.
Total quantity of items planned to be produced in the work order.
Actual quantity of finished goods produced as per the work order.
Quantity of defective or unusable materials generated during the production process.
Quantity of produced items delivered to inventory or next process stage.
Estimated standard time required to complete the work order based on production planning.
Actual time taken to complete the work order, used for performance analysis and efficiency tracking.
Duration of production downtime due to equipment breakdowns or operational interruptions.
Planned material cost estimated for the work order as per cost standards.
Actual material cost incurred during the production of the work order.
Estimated machine operating cost defined in the standard cost setup for the work order.
Actual machine operating cost recorded for the work order execution.
Expected labor cost planned as per standard production cost estimates.
Actual labor cost incurred during production operations for the work order.
Estimated overhead cost, including utilities and indirect labor, planned for the work order.
Actual overhead cost incurred in executing the work order.
Sum of all standard cost components (material, labor, machine, and overhead) for the work order.
Total actual cost recorded for completing the work order, used for cost variance analysis.
Standard cost per unit of the produced item as defined in cost planning.
Actual cost per unit of the produced item calculated after production completion.
Current status of the work order (e.g., Planned, In Progress, Completed, or Closed).
